subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit Test coverage - Statement complete

messageBody:
As someone who's had a chance to try most of these tools and use some of
them extensively at work, I wanted to throw in my 2 cents on these
tools.


Not free (both are around $600-700 minimum):
JProbe from Sitraka: http://www.sitraka.com/software/jprobe/
Can be run handily with the Ant <jpcoverage/> task in Ant 1.4/1.5. The
unsupported, open-source-produced Ant <jpcovreport/> task produces nicer
HTML reports than JProbe's commercial one. Source code line counts in
JProbe don't include abstract classes or interfaces or any class that
didn't get loaded at runtime, so they can be a little hard to fathom if
you use something like JavaNCSS to count your source. The Ant task can
produce more accurate counts of source code by using a reference path to
your source code. JProbe seems to run best with IBM 1.3 JVM on Windows.
Can hang (with any JVM) if there's heavy duty RMI usage in your tests or
classes. Needs lots of heap (at least -Xmx128m).

Borland's OptimizeIt Coverage (formerly VMgear):
http://www.borland.com/optimizeit/code_coverage/index.html. Fairly
recent addition to the OptimizeIt suite. I was in the beta and was
disappointed that they did nothing to improve on some of the lacking
features of JProbe (like branch coverage). Basically the same tool as
JProbe with a different UI. Might be worth looking into if you buy the
whole suite bundled with JBuilder.

As others already mentioned, Clover, which I like because it's
integrated with Ant out of the box, cheap as hell, and provides branch
coverage as well as the usual line and method coverage. Downside to
Clover is that you have to precompile all your code. Nice thing about
JProbe and OptimizeIt is that they can run on class files or jar files
with no precompilation step necessary. But the Clover reports are the
best looking of all and the price is right: $125 for one user. Not sure
how accurate the source line summaries are off the top of my head, but I
would expect them to be pretty accurate since it uses Antlr to
instrument the source rather than runtime bytecode instrumentation.

Compuware/NuMega have a code coverage tool in DevPartner TrueCoverage
for Java. Similar to JProbe and OptimizeIt except it also supports code
coverage for C code. Ditto for PureCoverage, the Rational code coverage
tool. I didn't like the PureCoverage GUI, and the tool required a
precompilation step.

Best,

Scott Stirling
Framingham, MA

> I know two commercial tools that offer support for
> showing/determining test coverage:
> 1) JTest from Parasoft (very expensive tool), see
http://www.parasoft.com
2) QStudio for Java from QA Systems (less expensive) see
http://www.qa-systems.com/downloads/qstudioforjava/index.html

Support for JUnit testing, coverage information and creating your own
codingstandard checks will be available in QStudio for Java by the end
of this year.
